citation.article-title: Transfer of Listeria denitrificans to a new genus Jonesia gen. nov., as Jonesia denitrificans comb. nov.

p.s: Description of Jonesia Rocourt and Stackebrandt gen. nov.
Jonesia (Jones.' i.a. L. fem. n. Jonesia of Jones, honoring Dorothy Jones, British microbiologist)
The genus description is taken mainly from that given in Bergey's Manual of Systematic Bacteriology, vol. 2 , by Seeliger and Jones.
It has to be kept in mind that the description is based upon the characterization of a single isolate only.
Irregular, nonsporing rods (0.3 by 0.5 μm) showing branched Y- and clublike forms.
Gram positive, but many cells, especially in older cultures, are readily decolorized.
Filamentous and coccoid cells may also occur in older cultures.
Colonies on nutrient agar are 0.5 to 1.5 mm in diameter (24 to 48 h), convex, smooth, grayish, and translucid to opaque, becoming yellowish in 10 to 20 days.
Cell wall contains murein of the L-lysteinserine-D-glutamic acid type (A4α and teichoic acid of the poly(ribitol phosphate) type (ribitol-galactosamine-galactose, 1:0.2:0.1).
Predominant fatty acids are anteiso-C15:0, anteiso-C17:0, and iso-C16:0.
Polar lipids are constituted by diphosphatidylglycerol, phosphatidylinositol, two phosphoglycolipids, and small amounts of two unidentified phospholipids.
Moles percent guanine plus cytosine, 54 to 58 (melting temperature method); 57 (Bd).
The type species of the genus is phylogenetically related to the genera Promicromonospora, Arthrobacter, Micrococcus, and Cellulomonas and allied taxa.
The type species is Jonesia denitri Jicans (PrCvot 1961) comb. nov.
